comments.commentBody:
There' s no evidence that Ayers and Obama had any greater connection than a few casual encounters at large group events ... but since when do right-wing Obama-haters need evidence?
And God forbid I should be held accountable for everything ever said by everyone who happened to be pastor at a church I belonged to. I just spent a few minutes at a website I accidentally stumbled upon, reading its claims that the Protocols of the Elders of Zion are real. Gee, I guess I'm an anti-Semite, too.

Earnest???
Yeah, 'well, then obviously I apologize' (for an action he claims not to remember, but is somehow simultaneously certain about what was not the motive for it) simply reeks of earnestness.

Bencharif,  do not defame those with Asperger's syndrome by linking them with the shape-shifting of Romney.  Although Asperger's syndrome sometimes makes it hard for those with it to understand how others feel, it also is associated with honesty and trustworthiness.
Special points for "sub-mediocre weasel-rat."

Exactly. This was not the only incident recounted in the article. How about intentionally steering a blind teacher into a closed door and then laughing hysterically?  Or  shouting "Atta girl!" repeatedly whenever a fellow student spoke?  His wife keeps saying what a "prankster" he is, but these incidents are evidence of a mean, bullying personality that enjoys hurting others.

I totally disagree with the attempt to pass on Romneys anti-social character by dismissing his adolescent cruelty. The type of person to do this is sick. Romney  the adult scores 100 on the psychopath check list. If people don't go with their gut reaction to this guy, we are in for some bad times. He has no empathy or regrets about his childhood or his adult work trashing companies for money, money and more  money. He should be kept as far from the oval office as possible.

Hispanic isn't a race.  It's an ethnicity.  Some Hispanics are white, some are black, and (especially in Peru) some are Asian.  This has been the case since the original "hispanic" census designation 25 years ago.

And you write your article in a newspaper that recently decided, by fiat and expediency, that I, along with Mr. Zimmerman, will belong to a new race: "White Hispanic". I am waiting for a reference to the tenant at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue as a "White African American".

By the way, perhaps your facts need to be revised. It appears that Ms. Warren did what it is claimed she did... there is no proof, as of yet, that she is native american.

If she lied, the only thing that remains to be clarified is why did she do it. I do not think it was to get a free lunch.

I believe Mr. Egan's point is to compare the self-awareness of the current candidates about the "dumb things Romney and Obama did before age 25".
That is, it's not what they did then, it's whether in the present day they can admit to errors, whether they currently show the same troubling behaviors and whether they ever reflected on their own lives and resolved to do better.

Let's resolve this once and for all. Mr Egan, you make a list of all the dumb things Romney and Obama did before age 25 and we can set back and compare. But lets get one thing straight. No rumors. You have to be able to prove the items on your list are true. And no cheating. We will just assume each list begins with "eating dog" and "driving dog". After we compare lists we will ask the question,
"what does our comparison reveal about the presidency
and the candidates qualifications.?" That's what we do in high school civics, might just as well do it here with all these smart folks.
Did you read the article? This was about Romney's current actions.

Speak for yourself, re bullying. Which is systematic tormenting that is not the same as getting into various scrapes.
It is known that teenager brains are not mature; they lack empathy - which makes many of them, more-or-less, low grade sociopaths until they mature. Still, bullies (who go on to become future criminals more often than others) are in a class by themselves.
But a mature adult should regret past bullying - assuming he/she hasn't matured into a genuine sociopath.

romney is a weasel allright and you can throw in draft dodging coward as well... he is what he is; a smug predator who likes to beat on people weaker than he is ... but he'll only attack when he's safe in a crowd of like minded cowards ... he remembers the incident, regardless of what he says, and deny's it with the arrogant laughter of a juvenile who's never had to account for his behavior ... it's not that far of a stretch to imagine what he'll be like if he get's elected ...

The economy is in the tank. There is the never ending conflict in the Middle East. There are major problems with our healthcare system. Here we are writing artcles on something Romney did when he was a teenager and inaccuratley calling it a "hate crime", because not a single one of us have ever "bullied" other students in highschool have we? *Sarcasm*. What is this election coming to?
A seven game series that featured three double overtime games including game seven.  The best Stanley Cup series ever; maybe the best in any sport.

“Someday I have to explain to Jaxon that the pain and difficulties that he endures every day are unnecessary and should have been prevented”?
Why would anyone ever tell a person such a thing? It is telling him that his life could/would have been prevented. That you would not have wanted him born. As unfortunate as it is to see his suffering, it would only add hurt and unkindness to tell him that.

My biological father passed on the susceptibility for Type 1 diabetes to me, his oldest daughter. The illness, thankfully, seems to have bypassed my younger sister and her two daughters (though they may still manifest, as it can show up in adults as well, though not as often as in children and teenaters). I ended up with this at age 11 and it has affected nearly all of the choices I've had to make in life. It's a lousy disease, not the worst I could have ended up with, but still a lousy, incurable, expensive-to-treat disorder. There's no good way of coming up with a genetic test for this, since the issue isn't one defective gene, but many good genes gone bad. I chose to forego having children for fear of passing this on to another person, like my father did to me. What worries me is that, as more and more adults end up with this (Type 1 diabetes in increasing by about 3% a year - not nearly as bad as Type 2, but still a significant increase) and many of these new cases are in adults. Now, what happens when someone who will eventually manifest as an adult Type 1 diabetic donates sperm to a bank? The symptons of beta cell destruction don't show up until nearly all of the insulin-producing cells in the pancreas are dead. A donor could potentially sire hundreds of Type 1 kids, since a Type 1 father has a 10% chance of passing it on, before he even knew he had the illness. And since 80% of us don't have any family history of Type 1, screening for it that way isn't helpful either.

I am a woman choosing donor insemination to start a family, due to my husband's severe male infertility due to adolescent testicular trauma and pediatric hernia surgeries.  On behalf of my husband  (and infertile women) I have to say that the idea that the infertile are somehow evolutionarily inferior is just an uneducated statement, or at least totally overbroad.  And, sadly, as comfortable as I am with our situation, the comments truly give me pause about telling anyone other than our closest confidants about our plans.  I am unimpressed by the level of education and sympathy among people on this topic.  Hopefully the commenters are not a true cross-section of the people we associate with.

I agree with your point. The question, however, is how many people will see the Republican obstructionism for what it was and understand that returning the Republicans to power would almost certain mean a new, deeper recession. If one is inclined not to believe that, then look to...Greece! and Europe, where austerity and currency problems are taking a terrible toll.

Make no mistake, the traditional role of Republicans since the end of the Great Depression has been to, first, slow the economy down upon entering office and, then, to let it go back up by stripping away government oversight and regulations. (The traditional Democrat's role has been to allow the economy to overheat in the name of full employment.)

The Republicans have made a mess of Washington, DC, for the 3+ yrs. of Obama, but it doesn't matter what has happened, it matters what people think has happened. Since they are generally not getting sharply defined straight reporting from the major media, or are getting biased spin from partisan media, the election is in doubt. I trust the ultimate wisdom of the voters (one more time!). Obama wins.

http://terryreport.com

Actually he probably doesn't need both -- either one will do. Real Clear Politics has 253 electoral votes as either solid or leaning Dem, and leaning means a reasonable lead (5% or more) in the average state poll. They have NH as a tossup but PPP's latest poll has Obama up there by double digits. If that's accurate, he's at 257 and either Ohio or Virginia puts him at the magic number.

For that matter, he could lose both and still win if he can carry CO, NH, and IA in addition to the 253 where he's leading now. And his prospects are very good in all three. Unless Romney can break into the 242 electoral votes in states that went for Kerry (and, of course, Obama as well), he has to run the table everywhere else.

I think the national polls are picking up the fact that in red states Obama is going to get clobbered but in purple ones he's going to do OK. He may be our fourth President to win office while losing the popular vote, largely because the red state vote will be so lopsided.

As for his popularity numbers, they omit the fact that there are many voters -- my guess is 5-10% of the samples -- who disapprove of Obama from the left but will still vote for him in November. If he goes into November even up in that index, he'll win.

3rd, my final point Auggie. You assert "[i]t is silly to look at anything but likely voters if you want to predict actual election results.'

That's not altogether true. it's not silly. As Nate cogently discussed "[u]sually a shift from registered voters to likely voters will improve the Republican candidate’s standing by a couple of points because Republican voters are older, wealthier and more likely to turn out in the average election. On the other hand, I do not think it is a good strategy to look solely at likely voter polls while ignoring the others. Some survey firms that use likely voter models have a history of a partisan skew in their polls that has nothing to do with the likely voter model itself."

Of course, that last sentence was a direct shot by Nate at Rasmussen.

I will grant you that as election day nears, polls surveying "likely voters" are likely to be more accurate than polls surveying "registered voters." But polls surveying "likely voters" are not that much more accurate than those surveying "registered voters" the farther out from election day. With 6 months to go prior to election day, I wouldn't put much stock in polls that just survey "likely voters." October would be a better indicator for such polls, and the day before the election would be the best indicator.

I have been thinking about your post for hours and must respond.

I believe we never lose our personhood; it is much more than "personality." True, the mental faculties of people with dementia deteriorate; they become unable to recognize loved ones, to form memories, and, in later stages, to perform the most basic of tasks and require total care. They may walk aimlessly, become agitated and combative. But, they never lose the life force that makes them who they are. They can respond to gentleness and may, at times, experience momentary awareness.

I work with people with dementia--in part, extending spiritual care to them. However we define sprituality, life force or for want of a better work "soul" ( I am not talking about rigid religious belief, here), I belive we can tap into it in some way even if a person is severely cognitively impaired. There is a lot of literature relating to spirituality, personhood and dementia. I have studied it etensively as part of a Mater's degree that I have just completed. Unfortunately, virtually all of the articles are not available full-text on the web. There also have been some very ecellent books published in this area.

I don't want to minimize in any way the devastation of dementia. Nor do I want to romanticize the caregiving that loved ones, and often nursing facilities, provide. We just cannot lose sight of the the individual person for whom we care or to whom we minister. He or she is much more than a biological shell.

Rossi did not deserve either of his injuries. If I were a U.S. soccer fan I would be happy to see how well he was doing in Spain and how much respect he garners.
Watching a few of Chandler's bundesliga games he actually displayed much more than he does for the U.S. He was used much more in the midfield and it allowed him more options than just running up the line using his weaker foot.

Lichaj should be a part of this initial camp. Absolutely ridiculous.
Chandler has a delusional belief he will play for Germany... not going to happen. And frankly speaking, we don't want him on our team because he won't have a very integral part of our being on a nat'l team, love of country and wanting to win for the USA! Do you think he would have pushed hard to beat Algeria like our boys did in South Africa??? No way.
Good riddance to him... and Rossi..... karma is a really big (insert word)!!!

Comment on multiple comments.
1). For those of you asking Nate to break down the election into predictions of the electoral college, just wait. You will not be disappointed.

2). For those of you touting the decrease in the participation rate both as a sign of a deteriorating economy and a primary reason that unemployment is decreasing, you are half right. Remember that there will be more boomers retiring than younger folks entering the job market throughout the next fifteen years. The fact that boomers are able to retire at this point is a good sign for the economy. It will also make the unemployment rate look to be improving faster than the economy overall. Also, although not headline grabbing the recent "disappointing" job number have all been revised upwards in succeeding months.

3). Just for fun, I looked at graphs for first time jobless claims, overlaying those of the recent recession on top of those from the Reagan recession. The graphs look almost identical except for a slight decrease (or false recovery) a few months after the initial peak during Reagan's time. Based on initial jobless claims this recession is recovering just as fast as that one. However, GDP recovery is still lagging.

4). I like the comment about Mr. Romney's favorability numbers improving now that he has made fewer public comments. If he says nothing until November 6, he may have a chance.

My children, if I manage to have them, will grow up knowing how hard we had to work to have them. So I think it will be very easy to have the conversation with any future daughters about the benefits of egg freezing and the insurance it provides (just insurance, not a guarantee).

After dealing with infertility for the past 5 years, I have a strong desire to go talk to graduate women's organizations at local universities to help educate them about fertility and infertility, as most women who need to understand it learn too late.

Another point - the implantation rates mentioned involve eggs that are as old as the women they were transferred to, not eggs that were frozen a decade before the woman chose to fertilize and transfer them.

Under age 30, about 50% of eggs are genetically normal. After age 40, it's more like 5-10% of eggs, so there's an enormous difference in when the eggs were retrieved.

I am assuming that you have conquered the age-old question of what to do with spent nuclear fuel rods ? Even if nuclear plants themselves were perfectly safe, they are one very expensive way to boil water. Even if nuclear plants themselves were perfectly safe, they still produce more fissionable material than mankind knows what to do with.

That, and the fact that Nuclear Plants are demonstrably *NOT* safe, is *why* the bottom fell out of the Nuclear Energy Industry back in the 70's. Ask an elder.

BTW, synthetic fuels IS a "greenie" proposal. Much can be accessed by simply switching off of Fox News from time to time.

A gift for Mr. Obama -- I don't think so!

This happened under Obama's watch at one of the "primo" financial institutions while the Fed, SEC and others were (once again) asleep at the wheel.

Will the SEC investigate Dimon for misleading shareholders with his "tempet in a teapot" comments? Unlikely since Obama seems infatuated with bankers -- willing to talk tough while holding his hand out for campaign donations.

What Romney needs to do when he is President is allow banks who want to bet the farm with their own money to die while insulating taxpayers from banker stupidity.

Obama had his chance to address this -- he failed -- his only consistent achievement as President.
Unreal, not so long ago the Republicans were hollering "faul" about the regulations. They never will learn. But will the public get wise?

Dimon did himself good by accepting the "stupid" and other more descriptive mistakes, readily and very soon. That doesn't mean he is Scot-free. Big "bosses of big, complex companies can" make big, bigger mistakes. And do, and flaunt about it --- at our expense.

FBI is now in, and the heats is on, once again after some short 2-3 years.

Romney again opposes needed regulations ? (Hope he doesn't flip-flop on this on: either way, a gift for you, Mr. Obama).

A gift that keeps on giving. Thank Mitt, Mr. Obama for Mitt's generosity.

Leapy, my favorite phrase from your post is "rotational symmetry." The arrangement of theme answers reminds me of a paper whirligig (is this what that propellery thingy with four wings is called? You blow on it, or run fast, and it spins). The NENE / ISIS pair would break the aerodynamic design.
Laszlo:  We called them pinwheels when I was a kid.  Perhaps it's because they were things you made yourself and used pins.

Pinwheel, of course! Doh...

Thanks.

Loved the rotational symmetry, and didn't in the least mind having it as an extra HINT HINT for the solve. That must have added an extra level of difficulty in construction. For complete perfect symmetry, 56a would have been ISIS, to match NENE.

AGAR AGAR reminded me of many culture plates I poured, back in the day, and GAMIN brought back Amelie, and a host of old Leslie Caron movies...Also fun to see MATZOS crossing TOAST and STRATA...

On a grimmer note, it's not easy to be a HEALER of exposure to the INSULATOR asbestos.

An excellent debut, Kevin A...a fine showing. Now, just where do those good-looking twins have their restaurant?

The so-called Dual Mandate, which Bruce interprets as a Triple Mandate, has actually morphed into a much larger mandate, which is part of the problem. I count roughly ten mandates.

During the formative period Bruce describes, several staffers were drafting legislation intended to reign in the Fed, an errand that ultimately proves impossible, because the Fed will not comply with any direction, but it has created a forum for an ongoing conversation through the semi-annual hearings, to which Dr. Paul, perhaps as a sort of swan song added the recent hearing in his subcommittee.

At the hearing, Jamie Galbraith described a process of drafting what became the Humphrey-Hawkins Act. My recollection is that the late Robert Weintraub, a student of Milton Friedman was in charge, and another participant, Robert Auerbach, who is a colleague of Jamie at the LBJ School and was also a student hand-picked by Friedman. Jamie spoke of his own involvement and that of another staffer and said they were able to agree among themselves on the formula that was adopted. Economists of left and right seem able to reach agreement where lawyers rarely will. The fourth participant was Jim Pierce, and economist from Berkeley, who along with Mary Pierce, led a study of financial institutions regulation that could have mitigated what has become the permanent financial crisis.

Dr. Weintraub believed that a fed chairman of either party would support a president of either party as both seek to continue.
